elements.content: The present work reports the construction and self-assembly studies of molecular helix and polyhedral coordination cages using a pyridine-pyrazole based asymmetric ligand. Employment of different metals has resulted in different architectures ranging from a one-dimensional helical polymer, [2 × 2] grid to a pentanuclear cage. For all the structures, hydrogen bonding and π–π stacking were found to be instrumental in bringing additional stability to the polymeric networks. Furthermore, chirality and magnetic properties of cobalt and copper complexes have also been investigated.
elements.clean_text: The present work reports the construction and self-assembly studies of molecular helix and polyhedral coordination cages using a pyridine-pyrazole based asymmetric ligand. For all the structures, hydrogen bonding and π-π stacking were found to be instrumental in bringing additional stability to the polymeric networks. Furthermore, chirality and magnetic properties of cobalt and copper complexes have also been investigated.

elements.content: We report herein a series of interesting metal-directed architectures based on a pyridine-pyrazole based asymmetric ligand. The semirigid ligand adopts different conformation and coordination modes while reacting with different metals and subsequently results in a molecular helix, [2 × 2] grid, and pentanuclear cage formation. Furthermore, the solid state CD spectra of the polyhedral coordination cages and magnetic properties of a tetranuclear copper grid have also been investigated.
elements.clean_text: We report herein a series of interesting metal-directed architectures based on a pyridine-pyrazole based asymmetric ligand. The semirigid ligand adopts different conformation and coordination modes while reacting with different metals and subsequently results in a molecular helix, [2 × 2] grid, and pentanuclear cage formation. Furthermore, the solid state CD spectra of the polyhedral coordination cages and magnetic properties of a tetranuclear copper grid have also been investigated.

elements.content: The studies of metallomacrocycles have attracted tremendous research attention because of their remarkable structural variety and various potential applications in the field of magnetism, bioinorganic chemistry, and host–guest chemistry. Over the years, great efforts have been devoted to study the self-assembly of polyhedral coordination cages, helical polymers, or grid structures. The correct choice of the metal center and rational design of the ligand system with finely tuned coordination behavior, backbone, and functionality are at the heart of the synthesis of these metallomacrocycles. In particular, using bis-bidentate bridging ligands to form larger metallocycles and cages has proved very rewarding for the understanding of basic fundamental factors governing the self-assembly of the supramolecular coordination complexes.Accordingly, bis-bidentate ligand molecules with various functional groups, conformations, and backbones or spacers between the coordinating sites have been extensively used. However, in the vast majority of the cases, the ligands have one structural feature in common, i.e., two chelating bidentate unit, typically, bipyridyl or pyrazolyl-pyridine units, connected to a central aromatic spacer, sometimes via flexible methylene “hinges”. In other words, most of the ligands are symmetrical in nature with two similar kinds of chelating coordinating sites, usually bidentate, on either sides of the spacer. On the contrary, asymmetric ligands with two dissimilar chelating coordination compartments remain largely unexplored.

elements.content: Motivated by the above-mentioned facts, we explore the possibility of forming metallocycles using an asymmetric chelating ligand, 3-(pyridine-2-yl)-N′-((pyridine-2-yl) methylene)-1-H-pyrazole-5-carbohydrazide (H2PMPC). H2PMPC has two terminal chelating units, a pyridine-pyrazole moiety and one pyridine-imine moiety. Therefore, one can expect it to exhibit coordination behavior similar to those of bis-bidentate ligands. On top of that, the presence of a 1-H pyrazole moiety and an amide group in the backbone, both capable of forming strong hydrogen bonding, along with an extended π-system of pyridyl-pyrazole unit makes H2PMPC an interesting ligand for studying the self-assembly process of the resultant supramolecular coordination complexes. Another point of interest is the semirigid backbone of the ligand. The H2PMPC, unlike other relevant ligands, does not have any spacer group or flexible hinge in its backbone. Therefore, it will be interesting to see whether the rigidity or lack of it has any impact on the self-assembly process.

elements.content: The ligand H2PMPC was synthesized by the reaction of 2-formyl pyridine with 3-(pyridin-2-yl)-1H-pyrazole-5-carbohydrazide in refluxing ethanol at 80 °C for 6 h. The ligand was fully characterized using IR, NMR, mass spectroscopy and single crystal X-ray crystallography. The structural analysis of the ligand reveals a nearly coplanar arrangement of pyrazole and pyridine rings. Although the pyrazole-pyridine moiety adopts a favorable chelating orientation, pyridine-imine moiety, however, adopt a trans orientation. Such spatial orientation of the ligand molecule can be attributed to the greater amount of hydrogen bond formation. As illustrated in Figure , the amide N–H and imine C–H form strong hydrogen bonds with carbonyl oxygen atom in an interesting fashion that closely resembles the self-assembly of ureas. While pyrazole N–H forms a strong N–H···N hydrogen bond with the pyridine N-atom, further stability comes from extensive π–π stacking among the aromatic rings.
elements.clean_text:
Result and Discussion

Synthesis and Crystal Structure

The ligand H2PMPC was synthesized by the reaction of 2-formyl pyridine with 3-(pyridin-2-yl)-1H-pyrazole-5-carbohydrazide in refluxing ethanol at 80 °C for 6 h. The ligand was fully characterized using IR, NMR, mass spectroscopy and single crystal X-ray crystallography. The structural analysis of the ligand reveals a nearly coplanar arrangement of pyrazole and pyridine rings. Although the pyrazole-pyridine moiety adopts a favorable chelating orientation, pyridine-imine moiety, however, adopt a trans orientation. Such spatial orientation of the ligand molecule can be attributed to the greater amount of hydrogen bond formation. As illustrated in Figure , the amide N-H and imine C-H form strong hydrogen bonds with carbonyl oxygen atom in an interesting fashion that closely resembles the self-assembly of ureas. While pyrazole N-H forms a strong N-H⋅⋅⋅N hydrogen bond with the pyridine N-atom, further stability comes from extensive π-π stacking among the aromatic rings.

elements.content: Crystal structure of H2PMPC showing (a) almost collinear arrangement of aromatic rings and (b) hydrogen bonding patterns.

elements.content: In order to evaluate the potential of H2PMPC as a precursor to produce supramolecular metallocycles, we explore the syntheses of coordination complexes by varying metal centers. Accordingly, compound 1 ({[Mn (H2PMPC)­(MeCN)2]­·2(ClO4)} n ) was synthesized through the reaction of Mn(ClO4)2 with H2PMPC in acetonitrile yielding plate-shaped light yellow crystals. Compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic P21/c space group with one Mn atom, one H2PMPC molecule, two coordinated acetonitrile molecules, and two noncoordinated perchlorate anions in the asymmetric unit. We were gratified to note that the H2PMPC molecule indeed behaves like a bis-bidentate ligand with two asymmetric chelating compartments. As expected, pyridine-pyrazole and pyridine-imine groups coordinate to two Mn atoms from two termini. The Mn atom exhibits a distorted triangular prism geometry and is coordinated to two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N3) from the pyridine-pyrazole terminal of one ligand and two more nitrogen atoms (N5 and N6) from the imine-pyridine terminal of another ligand. While the remaining two coordination sites are occupied by two acetonitrile molecules. Interestingly, coordination to metal center brings some subtle changes in the ligand conformation. The terminal pyridine rings move away from the linear arrangement of the free ligand with the CO group now pointing in the opposite direction.

elements.content: From a topological point of view, the complex 1 features an interesting 1D helical network sustained by π–π stacking and weak interactions (Figure a,c). These infinite helical chains are extended along the crystallographic b axis, and the distance of the repeating parts of the helices or the pitch length can be defined by the alternate Mn···Mn distance of 8.745 Å. The most fascinating feature of the structure would be the nature of the helical chains. A closer inspection of the structure reveals an intriguing aspect of the handedness of helical chains with the coexistence of two kinds of helical networks, a left-handed and a right-handed helical network (Figure b). The alternate helical chain is comprised of one particular type of helical chain, either left-handed or right-handed. In the overall packing mode, two types of chiral chains crystallize in pairs in a space group P21/c with an inversion center, leading to a racemic solid state compound. Such an arrangement of helical chains is sustained by strong π–π stacking and CO···π interactions. As illustrated in Figure c, the pyridine-pyrazole moiety of one helix comes very close to the pyridine-imine part of the adjacent helix and results in strong π–π interactions.

elements.content: Another, fascinating aspect of the structure is anion encapsulation with the participation of perchlorate ion as “supramolecular glue” among the helical networks in the form of hydrogen bonds and intermolecular interactions. The perchlorate ions occupy the cavity inside the helical networks and adopt an interesting orientation so that all four oxygen atoms can take part in various N–H···O, C–H···O bonds as well as anion-π interactions (Figure ), providing further stability to the network. Conformational change observed in the ligand, especially the relative spatial orientation of CO group with respect to other coordinating sites, shows some promising features. The CO group is not only pointing in the same direction to the pyridine-imine moiety but also ideally situated to coordinate to the metal center. In other words, this simple change in conformation of the ligand raises the prospect of introducing another asymmetric coordinating feature in H2PMPC, again with two different chelating termini, but with one tridentate compartment.

elements.content: Indeed, the two terminals of the ligand adopt distinctly different bidentate and tridentate chelating coordination modes when reacted with cobalt salt. Reaction of Co(BF4)2 with H2PMPC in a mixture of ethanol and DMF in a 2:3 ratio afforded block-shaped deep pink crystals of complex 2 ([Co5(HPMPC)6­(BF4)4·14H2O]. A change in the metal center not only diversifies the coordination mode of the ligand molecule but also changes the overall supramolecular structure. The complex crystallizes in tetragonal I4̅2d space group with five cobalt atoms having octahedral geometry, six HPMPC molecules, and four BF4 anions in the asymmetric unit.

elements.content: Single crystal structure analysis reveals formation of an interesting discrete M5L6 type cage for 2, with one bridging ligand spanning each of the edges of the Co5 pentahedron (Figure ). The Co5 pentahedron is highly irregular with the Co–Co–Co angles varying between 51.1–75.5°, and separation between Co atoms within the petahedron is in the range of 7.53–10.93 Å. Apparently, the asymmetric nature of the ligand molecule has a clear impact on the local coordination environment of the metal centers and results in two different types of Co centers. Two diagonally oriented Co centers have facial tris-chelate geometry, resulting from the coordination with three bidentate pyrazolyl-pyridine termini. The remaining three Co centers, on the other hand, coordinated only two tridentate termini and results in cis isomers. Such coordination modes coupled with the absence of a typical aromatic spacer group between the chelating units in the ligand result in a distinctly different type of π–π stacking. Notwithstanding, intracage interligand π–π stacking, which are a hallmark for molecular cages, are absent for complex 2. Instead, an extensive yet systematic π–π stacking around the periphery of the complex dominates the supramolecular self-assembly. Six ligands while coordinating to the metal centers create six sockets around the periphery of the pentahedron with a parallel arrangement of aromatic rings. The pyridine rings adopt such an interesting orientation so that another set of pyridine rings of the juxtaposed cage can undergo interdigitation resulting in a closely packed π–π stacking of four aromatic rings (Figure ). This results in an interesting supramolecular self-assembly with each cage molecule surrounded by six other cages, tightly tied with π–π stacking. Another interesting supramolecular feature of this complex is the amount of porosity observed, both inside the cage as well as the cavity resulting from the overall packing. The volume of the total solvent accessible voids is in the range of 15028.2 Å3, which is in the normal range for these kinds of cage molecules. However, the overall void space determined from PLATON reveals the presence of a staggering 25.5% porosity inside structure. It is noteworthy here that coordination cages, with some fine-tuning, can be of great importance in host–guest chemistry and the potential of complex 2 as a host will be explored in our future endeavors.

elements.content: Apparently, the ligand shows a clear trend of forming metal-dependent structures, and the reaction with Cu(II) was no exception. Reaction of Cu (ClO4)2 with H2PMPC in a 1:2:2 ratio in a methanol/chloroform/DMF solution led to block-shaped dark green crystals of complex 3 ([Cu4(PMPC)4]). X-ray single crystal structure analysis confirms another interesting structure with a [2 × 2] grid topology (Figure ). The change in the structure can be attributed to yet another change in the coordination modes of the ligand, this time with the involvement of amide N and the pyrazole ring. In a stark contrast to the previous structures, the ligand appears in a doubly deprotonated state with a deprotonated pyrazole ring now coordinate to the metal as a bidentate pyrazolate form. Interestingly, the ligand still retains its asymmetric nature with two distinct, bidentate and tridentate, binding compartments, although the amide CO group does not take part in metal coordination and points in the opposite direction. The complex crystallizes in tetragonal P4̅21 c space group with four PMPC2– molecules coordinating to four copper atoms to generate a tetranuclear [2 × 2] grid type complex. All four copper centers adopt a square pyramidal geometry by coordinating to the bi- and tridentate compartments of two ligands in a head-to-tail arrangement. As far as the supramolecular arrangement is concerned, the complex shows an extensive π–π stacking around the periphery of the complex (Figure ). Similar to the stacking pattern of 2, four ligands adopt an interesting orientation so that four sets of parallel aromatic rings protrude from the Cu4 core and expand in four directions. Subsequently, another four sets of aromatic rings from four surrounding grids undergo stacking with the help of strong face-to-face as well as edge-to-face π–π stacking.

elements.content: The conformational freedom of the ligand often plays a crucial role in determining both the dimensionality and topology of the final structure. This is especially true for a semirigid ligand molecule such as H2PMPC. Apparently, the structural diversity observed for compounds 1–3 can be directly linked to the different resultant conformations of the H2PMPC. A superimposed picture of H2PMPC (Figure ) will put this into perspective. It is quite remarkable to achieve such flexibility even in the absence of any flexible “hinge”. Depending on the coordination requirements, the H2PMPC molecule adopts different conformations via bending, stretching, or twisting of the rings, while for compound 3, this difference is even more pronounced and could be attributed to the bidentate coordination nature of the pyrazolate ring.
elements.clean_text:
Conformation vs Coordination Mode

The conformational freedom of the ligand often plays a crucial role in determining both the dimensionality and topology of the final structure. This is especially true for a semirigid ligand molecule such as H2PMPC. Apparently, the structural diversity observed for compounds 1-3 can be directly linked to the different resultant conformations of the H2PMPC. A superimposed picture of H2PMPC (Figure ) will put this into perspective. It is quite remarkable to achieve such flexibility even in the absence of any flexible "hinge". Depending on the coordination requirements, the H2PMPC molecule adopts different conformations via bending, stretching, or twisting of the rings, while for compound 3, this difference is even more pronounced and could be attributed to the bidentate coordination nature of the pyrazolate ring.

elements.content: The magnetic properties of 3 are shown in Figure in the form of temperature vs χM T. The χM T value of 3 is 1.52 cm3 K mol–1 at 290 K, which is minutely larger than that for four noninteracting Cu(II) ions with S = 1/2; χM T value is expected to be 1.5 cm3 K mol–1 with a g value of 2.00. The value decreases monotonically with decreasing temperature, reaching a value of 1.31 cm3 K mol–1 at 50 K. Below this temperature, the χM T value decreases sharply and reached a value of 0.03 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K. It suggests that the magnetic behavior of 3 is dominated by the antiferromagnetic exchange interactions between the four 2Eg copper(II) ions, as confirmed by the decrease of χM T value upon decreasing temperature. Inspection of the molecular structure of 3 reveals that the Cu···Cu separations of 4.166 Å are the same in the tetranuclear core.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Studies

The magnetic properties of 3 are shown in Figure  in the form of temperature vs χM T. The χM T value of 3 is 1.52 cm3 K mol-1 at 290 K, which is minutely larger than that for four noninteracting Cu(II) ions with S = 1/2; χM T value is expected to be 1.5 cm3 K mol-1 with a g value of 2.00. The value decreases monotonically with decreasing temperature, reaching a value of 1.31 cm3 K mol-1 at 50 K. Below this temperature, the χM T value decreases sharply and reached a value of 0.03 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K. It suggests that the magnetic behavior of 3 is dominated by the antiferromagnetic exchange interactions between the four 2Eg copper(II) ions, as confirmed by the decrease of χM T value upon decreasing temperature. Inspection of the molecular structure of 3 reveals that the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu separations of 4.166 Å are the same in the tetranuclear core.

elements.content: Traditionally, employment of optically active ligands and sometimes the use of chiral templates has remained the most popular technique for synthesis of chiral complexes. However, recent reports suggest that spontaneous resolution can be a useful technique for generating chiral inorganic complexes. In the current context, the compound 2 and 3, which crystallizes in chiral space groups of I4̅2d and P4̅21 c, respectively, offers an interesting system for the study of spontaneous resolution. Further encouragements come from the Flack parameter values of compounds 2 and 3 (0.00(6) and 0.005(7), respectively). Accordingly, the circular dichroism studies were performed by a diffused reluctance technique over the KBr matrix. Both the compounds responded positively to CD studies with small dichroic signals characteristic of solid state CD spectra. Compound 2 showed a positive Cotton effect with a broad signal around 585 nm, and for compound 3 another positive Cotton effect was observed with the dichroic signal appearing around 350 nm (Figure ). Ideally, crystallization of compounds 2 and 3 owing to spontaneous resolution should result in formation of both the enantiomers. However, even after repeating the CD studies with several crystals (10 crystals of both compounds) from different batches, we were unable to record the opposite cotton effect for both the compounds which prompts us to assume the formation of enantiopure compounds or at least an enantiomeric excess has been achieved, whereas the origin of chirality can be directly linked to the spatial arrangement of metals atoms, a tetrahedron Cu4 and a pentahedron Co5 core for complexes 2 and 3, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Solid State CD Analysis of Compounds 2 and 3 

Traditionally, employment of optically active ligands and sometimes the use of chiral templates has remained the most popular technique for synthesis of chiral complexes. However, recent reports suggest that spontaneous resolution can be a useful technique for generating chiral inorganic complexes. In the current context, the compound 2 and 3, which crystallizes in chiral space groups of I4̅2d and P4̅21 c, respectively, offers an interesting system for the study of spontaneous resolution. Further encouragements come from the Flack parameter values of compounds 2 and 3 (0.00(6) and 0.005(7), respectively). Accordingly, the circular dichroism studies were performed by a diffused reluctance technique over the KBr matrix. Both the compounds responded positively to CD studies with small dichroic signals characteristic of solid state CD spectra. Compound 2 showed a positive Cotton effect with a broad signal around 585 nm, and for compound 3 another positive Cotton effect was observed with the dichroic signal appearing around 350 nm (Figure ). Ideally, crystallization of compounds 2 and 3 owing to spontaneous resolution should result in formation of both the enantiomers. However, even after repeating the CD studies with several crystals (10 crystals of both compounds) from different batches, we were unable to record the opposite cotton effect for both the compounds which prompts us to assume the formation of enantiopure compounds or at least an enantiomeric excess has been achieved, whereas the origin of chirality can be directly linked to the spatial arrangement of metals atoms, a tetrahedron Cu4 and a pentahedron Co5 core for complexes 2 and 3, respectively.

elements.content: In summary, we have successfully synthesized diverse metal-directed architectures using an asymmetric bis-chelating ligand. The crystal structures show that both conformational freedom as well as coordination flexibility of the semirigid ligand has an important influence on the resulting networks. One of the promising features of the Co5 coordination cage is the presence of distinct void and channels within the network. The potential of this ligand to produce porous coordination cages and their host–guest chemistry is currently under investigation in our laboratory.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we have successfully synthesized diverse metal-directed architectures using an asymmetric bis-chelating ligand. The crystal structures show that both conformational freedom as well as coordination flexibility of the semirigid ligand has an important influence on the resulting networks. One of the promising features of the Co5 coordination cage is the presence of distinct void and channels within the network. The potential of this ligand to produce porous coordination cages and their host-guest chemistry is currently under investigation in our laboratory.

elements.content: All reagents used in the present work were obtained commercial sources and were used without further purification unless otherwise stated. FT-IR spectra were obtained on a Nicolet MAGNA-IR 750 spectrometer with samples prepared as KBr pellets. C, H, and N microanalyses were carried out with a 2400 Series-II CHN analyzer, Perkin-Elmer, USA, and CD spectra were collected using a JASCO J-815 CD spectrometer. Magnetic data were collected by MPMS (Evercool, 7 T) by Quantum Design, 1H NMR was carried out by Bruker spectrometer operating at 400 MHz in DMSO-d 6 solvent, and mass spectra were collected by Micro mass Q-Tof Micro instrument.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

All reagents used in the present work were obtained commercial sources and were used without further purification unless otherwise stated. FT-IR spectra were obtained on a Nicolet MAGNA-IR 750 spectrometer with samples prepared as KBr pellets. C, H, and N microanalyses were carried out with a 2400 Series-II CHN analyzer, Perkin-Elmer, USA, and CD spectra were collected using a JASCO J-815 CD spectrometer. Magnetic data were collected by MPMS (Evercool, 7 T) by Quantum Design, 1H NMR was carried out by Bruker spectrometer operating at 400 MHz in DMSO-d 6 solvent, and mass spectra were collected by Micro mass Q-Tof Micro instrument.

elements.content: The Shiff base of 3-(pyridin-2-yl)-N′-((pyridin-2-yl)­methylene)-1H-pyrazole-5-carbohydrazide was synthesized by the condensation of 3-(pyridin-2-yl)-1H-pyrazole-5-carbohydrazide and 2-pyridinecarboxaldehyde in a 1:1 molar ratio in ethanol in the presence of acetic acid as catalyst for 6 h. After the solution was cooled, a white precipitate formed which was filtered out and characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction, IR, mass and NMR spectrometer (yield: 77%).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of H2PMPC

The Shiff base of 3-(pyridin-2-yl)-N'-((pyridin-2-yl)methylene)-1H-pyrazole-5-carbohydrazide was synthesized by the condensation of 3-(pyridin-2-yl)-1H-pyrazole-5-carbohydrazide and 2-pyridinecarboxaldehyde in a 1:1 molar ratio in ethanol in the presence of acetic acid as catalyst for 6 h. After the solution was cooled, a white precipitate formed which was filtered out and characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction, IR, mass and NMR spectrometer (yield: 77%).

Synthesis of Compound <bold>1</bold>

({[Mn (H2PMPC)­(MeCN)2]­·2(ClO4)} n : 0.0292 g (0.01 mmol) of H2PMPC and 0.0253 g (0.01 mmol) of Mn(ClO4)2·xH2O were placed in a round-bottom flask containing 5 mL of acetonitrile, and the mixture was heated in an oil bath at 80 °C for 24 h. After slow cooling of the light yellow solution plate-shaped light yellow crystals of 1 which were suitable for X-ray data collection were obtained within two days; they were washed with acetonitrile and dried.

X-ray Crystallography

X-ray diffraction intensities for H2PMPC and compounds 1–3 were collected at 120 K on Bruker APEX-2 CCD and diffractometer using Mo Kα radiation and processed using SAINT. The structures were solved by direct methods in SHELXS and refined by full matrix least-squares on F 2 inSHELXL. Crystallographic data are summarized in Table , and CIF files for the structures reported in this paper have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC). Deposition numbers are given in Table . Copies of the data can be obtained, free of charge, on application to the CCDC, 12 Union Road, CambridgeCB2 1EZ UK (Fax: 44 (1223) 336 033; e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

IR (KBr cm–1): 3429(b), 1612(s) 1502(s), 1431(s), 1290(s), 1290(s).

Anal.calcd (found) for C96H82B4Co5F16N38O23 (%): C 41.47(39.76), H 2.95(3.39), N 19.15(17.97).

Synthesis of Compound <bold>3</bold>

([Cu4(PMPC)4]): A 0.037 g (0.01 mmol) solution of Cu(ClO4)2 in 2:1 CHCl3/MeOH was carefully layered onto a solution of H2PMPC, 0.0292 g (0.01 mmol) in 2 mL of DMF. After one and half months, dark green block-shaped crystals of 1 which were suitable for X-ray data collection were obtained; they were washed with chloroform and dried.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of H2PMPC

The Shiff base of 3-(pyridin-2-yl)-N'-((pyridin-2-yl)methylene)-1H-pyrazole-5-carbohydrazide was synthesized by the condensation of 3-(pyridin-2-yl)-1H-pyrazole-5-carbohydrazide and 2-pyridinecarboxaldehyde in a 1:1 molar ratio in ethanol in the presence of acetic acid as catalyst for 6 h. After the solution was cooled, a white precipitate formed which was filtered out and characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction, IR, mass and NMR spectrometer (yield: 77%).

Anal. calcd (found) for C17H15N7O (H2PMPC) (%): C, 61.64 (61.67); H, 4.10 (4.05); N, 28.76(28.67).

IR (400-4000 cm-1): 3436(b), 3299(s), 3074(s), 1674(s), 1533(s), 1226(s) .

 1H NMR (500 MHz, [(CD3)2SO], δ) 14.174 (s, 1H, pyz-H), 12.096 (s, 1H, NH), 8.650 (s, 1H, imine-H), 7.385-7.998 (8H, py-H).

ESI-MS m/z (M + H): 293.1258.

Synthesis of Compound 1 

({[Mn (H2PMPC)(MeCN)2]⋅2(ClO4)} n : 0.0292 g (0.01 mmol) of H2PMPC and 0.0253 g (0.01 mmol) of Mn(ClO4)2⋅xH2O were placed in a round-bottom flask containing 5 mL of acetonitrile, and the mixture was heated in an oil bath at 80 °C for 24 h. After slow cooling of the light yellow solution plate-shaped light yellow crystals of 1 which were suitable for X-ray data collection were obtained within two days; they were washed with acetonitrile and dried.

Yield: 63% based on H2PMPC.

Anal. calcd (found) for C19H18Cl2N8O9Mn (%): C, 36.29 (36.10); H, 2.86(2.61); N, 17.82 (17.94).

IR (KBr cm-1): 3427(b), 3207(b), 1641(s), 1566(s), 1091(s).

Synthesis of Compound 2 

([Co5(HPMPC)6(BF4)4⋅14 H2O]): 0.0292 g (0.01 mmol) of H2PMPC and 0.034 g (0.01 mmol) of Co(BF4)2 were placed in a round-bottom flask containing 3:2 DMF,/EtOH, and the mixture was heated in an oil bath at 80 °C for 30 h. After slow cooling of the pink solution, block-shaped dark pink crystals of 2 which were suitable for X-ray data collection were obtained after several days; they were washed with ethanol and dried in air.

Yield: 72% based on H2PMPC.

IR (KBr cm-1): 3429(b), 1612(s) 1502(s), 1431(s), 1290(s), 1290(s).

Anal.calcd (found) for C96H82B4Co5F16N38O23 (%): C 41.47(39.76), H 2.95(3.39), N 19.15(17.97).

Synthesis of Compound 3 

([Cu4(PMPC)4]): A 0.037 g (0.01 mmol) solution of Cu(ClO4)2 in 2:1 CHCl3/MeOH was carefully layered onto a solution of H2PMPC, 0.0292 g (0.01 mmol) in 2 mL of DMF. After one and half months, dark green block-shaped crystals of 1 which were suitable for X-ray data collection were obtained; they were washed with chloroform and dried.

cln_elements.content:
Single crystal structure analysis reveals formation of an interesting discrete M5L6 type cage for 2, with one bridging ligand spanning each of the edges of the Co5 pentahedron (Figure ). The Co5 pentahedron is highly irregular with the Co–Co–Co angles varying between 51.1–75.5°, and separation between Co atoms within the petahedron is in the range of 7.53–10.93 Å. Apparently, the asymmetric nature of the ligand molecule has a clear impact on the local coordination environment of the metal centers and results in two different types of Co centers. Two diagonally oriented Co centers have facial tris-chelate geometry, resulting from the coordination with three bidentate pyrazolyl-pyridine termini. The remaining three Co centers, on the other hand, coordinated only two tridentate termini and results in cis isomers. Such coordination modes coupled with the absence of a typical aromatic spacer group between the chelating units in the ligand result in a distinctly different type of π–π stacking. Notwithstanding, intracage interligand π–π stacking, which are a hallmark for molecular cages, are absent for complex 2. Instead, an extensive yet systematic π–π stacking around the periphery of the complex dominates the supramolecular self-assembly. Six ligands while coordinating to the metal centers create six sockets around the periphery of the pentahedron with a parallel arrangement of aromatic rings. The pyridine rings adopt such an interesting orientation so that another set of pyridine rings of the juxtaposed cage can undergo interdigitation resulting in a closely packed π–π stacking of four aromatic rings (Figure ). This results in an interesting supramolecular self-assembly with each cage molecule surrounded by six other cages, tightly tied with π–π stacking. Another interesting supramolecular feature of this complex is the amount of porosity observed, both inside the cage as well as the cavity resulting from the overall packing. The volume of the total solvent accessible voids is in the range of 15028.2 Å3, which is in the normal range for these kinds of cage molecules. However, the overall void space determined from PLATON reveals the presence of a staggering 25.5% porosity inside structure. It is noteworthy here that coordination cages, with some fine-tuning, can be of great importance in host–guest chemistry and the potential of complex 2 as a host will be explored in our future endeavors.

Magnetic Studies

The magnetic properties of 3 are shown in Figure in the form of temperature vs χM T. The χM T value of 3 is 1.52 cm3 K mol–1 at 290 K, which is minutely larger than that for four noninteracting Cu(II) ions with S = 1/2; χM T value is expected to be 1.5 cm3 K mol–1 with a g value of 2.00. The value decreases monotonically with decreasing temperature, reaching a value of 1.31 cm3 K mol–1 at 50 K. Below this temperature, the χM T value decreases sharply and reached a value of 0.03 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K. It suggests that the magnetic behavior of 3 is dominated by the antiferromagnetic exchange interactions between the four 2Eg copper(II) ions, as confirmed by the decrease of χM T value upon decreasing temperature. Inspection of the molecular structure of 3 reveals that the Cu···Cu separations of 4.166 Å are the same in the tetranuclear core.

The magnetic properties of 3 are shown in Figure  in the form of temperature vs χM T.
